intro: Amorphophallus aphyllus, commonly known as the naked-tuber arum, is a striking plant native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its large, showy inflorescence that resembles a phallic shape, which is why it is also called the "taro lily." The plant produces a single, large, leaf that emerges after the flowering period, making it easily distinguishable from other arum species. Its underground tuber is edible when properly prepared, though it contains calcium oxalate crystals that can be toxic if consumed raw. This plant thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often cultivated for its ornamental value.
